Where to buy

>Amiami - usual place for buying, to some people, shipping is a bit higher due to packaging

>Hobby Search Japan - items stay in stock the longest
>Mandarake - search figma or フィグマ
>eBay/Amazon - only if you hate having too much money. Avoid bootlegs, you can spot them as 'Chinese version'

>Check the BST threads, My Figure Collection for any offer/deal

I all inned the original Kickstarter because I wanted to support the line and was excited for articulated dinosaurs. No one had any in hand. I all inned the second Kickstarter because it was in many ways an improvement on the first- a better scale, more difference in the sculpts, and I wanted to support the line. There were issues in both that wound up not being apparent for years because the order window to when they came out was so long. I don't even remember if I had my raptors in hand when I ordered the triceratops figures. Also, "they're all repaints" they're actually not, which was one of my biggest criticisms with the line once it became apparent that each KS was going to take 2-3 years to come out. Spending all that time and money on barely different sculpts was and is a waste. Anyway my issue wasn't ever really with you, just saying when I had so many figures I'm well aware of their issues so someone coming in 5 years later with a "I just bought this figure maybe it's different" really didn't do anything for me. I thought I could shitpost in peace but there's a million faggots here apparently.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10141017
A lot of people all-in and I just don't see how they have the space for it. I do get what you mean though in terms of how long it takes waves to come out and all that, I understand it's just one guy and some chinese factory workers basically rather than a proper toy company, but it's taken 6-7 years since the line was announced before you could make an obligatory "T.Rex vs. Triceratops" sort of display.
I understand the whole "re-use molds for other figures" thing, it makes sense, and I'm sure theres budget reasons per-line, but it's still annoying. It's nice that it seems like there's more variety in the future though. Allosaurus is probably my favourite dinosaur and I had no idea when, if ever, I'd be able to get a BotM figure of one, let alone some morrison formation pals to go along with it. But seems like both an Allo and a Stego are in the forseeable future now, and not relegated to some sort of "Allosauroid" and "Thyreophoran" waves over the course of like 10 years or something.
In the end though I buy these at retail, I don't mess with the kickstarter, and I only buy what I want, so far my only issue I've had (and I consider it major), is that the plastic on the upper inner thigh of my adult Trike had a tear in it out of the box, and I have no idea how I'll repair that if it ever gets worse.

How do you guys feel about damaging/destroying your soldiers? Blowing up army men with firecrackers has certainly been a longstanding cliché but I never did that myself, even when I had the means. A broken soldier was always a great tragedy, I hated to throw one out and would do my best to repair them when possible. I also ordered some new Vallejo paints for Kong's skin, which will be kind of a dark warm gray.

threads.com:
Welcome to Lego Tabletop RPG

>What is it?
It's a gameplay philosophy for Lego. It's not competitive; it's a sandbox for adventure and storytelling.

Not all characters are pure combatants. Some make their journey through the world using other methods...

>How does it work?
We loosely borrow concepts from D&D, most notably the dice. Combat is much simpler and easy to follow for newbies. The game is developing over time in tandem with our Lego world. It's not competitive between players so the rules can be bent as necessary to facilitate enjoyable moments.

Lego is all about the joy of the moment.

>What's this thread?
For now I'll be chronicling the progression of characters in my world via these threads.

Each character has a choice of a few different starting spawns based on their character build.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>10137346
>mfw finally help a fellow /toy/anon
Feels good man

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10133806
Hasbro Rathtar came in and I finally had a chance for some quick testing today.

You have to put on the tentacles yourself. They are hard PVC-like plastic with some flexibility to them. As I expected soaking them in hot water makes them completely bendable and they will hold their shape once cooled down (pic related, before and after wrapping around the included figure). As they remain slightly flexible overbending is recommended to get tight grabs. The tentacles have different lengths, which straightened out they vary from 10 to 15cm. 2 of the tentacles have "grabber" tips, the others classic rounded tips.

The pegs and pegholes used for the tentacles are all the same shape and size so you can freely mix and match positions as you please, even if the instructions specify a specific order. However the tentacles are prone to falling off when inserted cold. Instead you want to heat up the pegs which gives them way a better fit. The instructions don't mention this which explains all the complaints from angry parents. As for movement, it only allows for rotation.

The mouth and teeth are soft PVC. The mouth's opening is 27mm wide and 22mm tall. The body is hard plastic and hollow. Measured from the mouth it goes 86mm deep. The sculpt has a lot of details which would benefit from a wash.

At €15 (€10 post gift card) I'd say it makes for a nice affordable option for degenerate uses. It might be annoying to pose and a bit small for larger figures, but definitely useable. Now to decide what figure I want to pose with it...

Toyline general info:
>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Figma

Max Factory figma list & blog
>http://www.figma.jp/en/figma

Reviews and news about GSC/MF products by Kahotan
>http://mikatan.goodsmile.info/en/
>http://ameblo.jp/gsc-mikatan/

Where to buy
>GSC Online Shop - some figmas only are available through their online shop
>Amiami - usual place for buying, to some people, shipping is a bit higher due to packaging
>Hobby Link Japan shipping is usual lower, but their prices are a bit higher, private warehaouse is available
>Hobby Search Japan - items stay in stock the longest
>Mandarake - search figma or フィグマ
>eBay/Amazon - only if you hate having too much money. Avoid bootlegs, you can spot them as 'Chinese version'
>http://jungle-scs.co.jp/ - Seems like you can fine some good deals here
>Check the BST threads, My Figure Collection for any offer/deal

Here's a link to the buyfag guide list of shops:
http://www.buyfags.moe/Full_guide#List_of_shops
If you're getting into the hobby, there's plenty of other useful information to find on the wiki.

In case someone is interested in the printable backdrops/dioramas & other papercraft stuff that Max Factory have in the download section of their site:
>http://www.maxfactory.jp/ja/mxf-downloads
here is a back up, Enjoy!
>https://www.mediafire.com/?7l9ar0z58cx43sa

Short illustrated posing guide by Max Factory
>http://ameblo.jp/figma/entry-11564427757.html (in moonrunes)
The S shape is always good advice though. The basic idea is that straight lines tend to look stiff.

Problems when swapping parts/accessories with your figmas? Check this advice
>http://www.goodsmile.info/en/post/3325

Tomytec's 1 inch scale section (1/12 stuff, little armory, vehicles and others)
>http://www.tomytec.co.jp/1inch/
